channel.title: Glen's Parallax Perspectives
channel.description: This is independent from any organization or political party. It provides information, analysis, and resources about a wide variety of issues and opportunities related to peace, nonviolence, social justice, economic justice, and how to make our world better.

item.description: Many Americans seem to accept Israel’s current cruelty to Palestinians. Israel’s Prime Minister Netanyahu TOTALLY REJECTED a “two-state” solution. He wants Israelis to dominate, with NO rights for Palestinians. Just now I wrote the attached analogy, which seems compelling. I encourage people to read and share it. Native Americans — Palestinians

item.title: Martin Luther King Was a Radical, Not a Moderate

Economics, Labor, Capitalism, Trade, Poverty (Also see Taxes)

item.description: King called himself a democratic socialist. He believed that America needed a “radical redistribution of economic and political power.” https://www.commondreams.org/views/2021/12/25/martin-luther-king-was-radical-not-moderate?vgo_ee=k2jIECcPP24SvUHOjogvWM%2Fa8rzVrD8A28fuZdXegaA%3D

item.title: How the Vietnam War pushed MLK to embrace global justice, not only civil rights at home
item.dc:creator: GlenAnderson
item.category: Economics, Labor, Capitalism, Trade, Poverty (Also see Taxes)
International Affairs (Click to see specific nations and regions)
Nonviolence (Also see Peace, Conflict Resolution, Organizing & Activism)
Our Current Political Crisis (in addition to Trump and Trumpism)
Peace (See Foreign Policy and specific nations and regions -- and ALSO see Military Spending and Nuclear Weapons)
item.description: How the Vietnam War pushed MLK to embrace global justice, not only civil rights at home It is a radical concept of love that demands we embrace those we know and those we don’t, to acknowledge, as King said, “that all life is interrelated, that somehow we’re caught in an inescapable network of mutuality tied in a single garment of destiny.” https://www.nationofchange.org/2022/01/13/how-the-vietnam-war-pushed-mlk-to-embrace-global-justice-not-only-civil-rights-at-home/

item.title: MLK was more radical and bold than “I have a dream.” See this.
item.dc:creator: GlenAnderson
item.category: Democracy, Electoral Reforms, Voting Rights (Also see Political Parties and Elections)
Economics, Labor, Capitalism, Trade, Poverty (Also see Taxes)
Nonviolence (Also see Peace, Conflict Resolution, Organizing & Activism)
Peace (See Foreign Policy and specific nations and regions -- and ALSO see Military Spending and Nuclear Weapons)
item.description: Ever since the Civil Rights Movement’s era, I have appreciated King’s strong, bold, radical message. I have read his books and studied him extensively.  I know a number of people who had worked very closely with him during the Movement, including the older white man sitting next to him on the first integrated bus in Montgomery, Alabama, in December 1956. For too many years people want to water him down to the “Dream” speech, because a “dream” is something not real – something possibly for the future – something that does not compel radical change now.  That is why the [...]

item.title: MLK’s speech when receiving Nobel Peace Prize on Dec. 11, 1964
item.dc:creator: GlenAnderson
item.category: Nonviolence (Also see Peace, Conflict Resolution, Organizing & Activism)
Peace (See Foreign Policy and specific nations and regions -- and ALSO see Military Spending and Nuclear Weapons)
item.description: In case you have not read this for a while, here it is again. It is always relevant and powerful.   Martin Luther King .Jr., delivered this speech on Dec. 11, 1964, when receiving Nobel Peace Prize   The quest for peace and justice It is impossible to begin this lecture without again expressing my deep appreciation to the Nobel Committee of the Norwegian Parliament for bestowing upon me and the civil rights movement in the United States such a great honor. Occasionally in life there are those moments of unutterable fulfillment which cannot be completely explained by those symbols [...]

item.title: MLK affirmed BOTH Israel and Palestine. Israel must return land it stole.
item.dc:creator: GlenAnderson
item.category: International Affairs (Click to see specific nations and regions)
Peace (See Foreign Policy and specific nations and regions -- and ALSO see Military Spending and Nuclear Weapons)
item.description: Martin Luther King, Jr., strongly supported peace, nonviolence, and social justice in many ways. He affirmed BOTH Israel and Palestine. He said Israel’s government must return the land it stole from Palestinian people. See this recent item reporting on what he had said in 1967: We Don’t Have to Guess What MLK Thought About the Israel-Palestine Conflict – Mother Jones

item.title: When Democrats nominate war-hawks for president, Republicans win by running as peace candidates
item.dc:creator: GlenAnderson
item.category: Democracy, Electoral Reforms, Voting Rights (Also see Political Parties and Elections)
International Affairs (Click to see specific nations and regions)
Our Current Political Crisis (in addition to Trump and Trumpism)
Peace (See Foreign Policy and specific nations and regions -- and ALSO see Military Spending and Nuclear Weapons)
Political Parties and Elections (Also see Democracy ...)
item.description: In the spring of 1968, President Johnson realized that his horribly unpopular war in Vietnam would PREVENT him from being re-elected, so he withdrew from his presidential campaign.  His VP, Hubert Humphrey, became the Democratic nominee.  But instead of listening to the public, which opposed the Vietnam War, Humphrey campaigned as a pro-war candidate. Richard Nixon campaigned as a “peace” candidate with a promise to end the war, so voters elected Nixon, even though he was horrible in every other way. Leading up to 2016, the Democratic Party kept promoting Hillary Clinton as the only candidate it would consider.  (Remember [...]

item.description: In addition to the TV programs I have listed below, I have produced many other TV programs about peace, excessive military spending, changing to a nonviolent foreign policy, grassroots organizing to make bold improvements in our society, etc.  See links to ALL TV programs since January 2018 at this part of my blog:  https://parallaxperspectives.org/category/tv-programs-parallax-perspectives-series   Here are links to the TV programs specifically focusing on nuclear weapons:   January 2024:  “U.N. Update on Nuclear Weapons Treaty”:  https://parallaxperspectives.org/u-n-update-on-nuclear-weapons-treaty   March 2023:  “Smart Strategies to Organize for Peace and No Nuclear Weapons”:  https://parallaxperspectives.org/tv-online-smart-strategies-to-organize-for-peace-and-no-nuclear-weapons   January 2023:  “Three Steps to Nuclear Disarmament”:  https://parallaxperspectives.org/three-steps-to-nuclear-disarmament [...]
